meeting_annotations.speaker: Jordi Cabana
meeting_annotations.transcript: Single pass conversion. Okay. Um so you know, when you look inside the reactor, what is, you know, what is driving that that competition? Is that something that um is as simple as reactor design or is it just that your catalyst cannot transform fast enough?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wilson Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's reactor design and um again the electrolyte. So if you're doing CO2, um even if you start with a basic electrolyte, if you start to run it more than 10 or 20 milliamps, it's going to become alkaline spontaneously. So it's the electrolyte consumption, but then with the with the kind of transport control, there are things like pressure drops that will change and it depends on if you're making CO2 to CO, so a gas feed stock to a gas product, the the pressure drop across the electrode will be small. But if you want to make a liquid product, you will create a much bigger pressure drop across your electrode and the effects down the channel will be much more significant. So it's there there's a lot of competing factors, which is why I think, you know, CO2 electrolysis won't scale the same way that water electrolysis does. You know, selectivity is not an issue for water electrolysis.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a presentation slide titled "NEXT GENERATION ELECTROCHEMISTRY".
